title: AKDMKS : Akademiks clothing : 007 : "Red Script Tag"
content:
Akademiks is an NYC-based clothing company, established in 1999. I am posting a series of fonts used by Akademiks. Please help me ID the fonts.

"Red Script Tag"

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20110508004924im_/http:/typophile.com/files/akademiks-red-script-tag_4396.jpg)

007
author: dirtcastle

comments.content:
Out of all the ones I posted, this is the one I really wanted to figure out.

Without a doubt, some or most of it is customized. I am guessing that the designer started with a non-stencil serif and made it into a stencil.

It would be nice to at least figure out the original font(s) that got tweaked.

Eric, I think you're right that it's a faux-stencil. Judging from some of the other samples you posted these guys seem to go for antique/obscure fonts and then cobble them up. Both k's in this sample seem clumsily altered.

When I think about these letters, it looks like the lower case letters are a monotone serif (either italic or slanted Roman -- that 'a' style is not a script 'a', and most of the time it's not even an italic one), and the A and S may be from script fonts. The A sort of resembles [Bellevue](http://web.archive.org/web/20110508004924/http:/new.myfonts.com/search/bellevue%C2%AE/fonts/) in having the straight right stroke with the arched left curve. I don't know what to say about that S. Really.

I'll try to think about an italic serif that might resemble these lower case letters.

- Mike Yanega

Thank you, Mike. Your hard work on this series of IDs is greatly appreciated.

Ya, now that I look at it, the cobbled parts do stick out a little more. But I think the sloppiness gives it an appealing organic/signish/graf look. And when holding the actual tag, the cobbled parts aren't as noticeable as when it is scanned and placed in 2D.

I will also give this ID a shot myself.
